I Spent Less Than 2 Days in Dublin and I Ate at Bread 41 Bakery 3 Times | Bon Appétit

Even when I love a place, going back means I’m missing an opportunity to try somewhere new. And as a BA editor with a serious case of FOMO, I always want to try somewhere new.But when I was in Dublin this past summer, Bread 41 made me break my no-repeat rule. I first walked in because my husband suggested it—he read the words “long-fermented sourdough,” “organic ancient grains,” and “house-milled flour” and figured I’d be interested. (He was right.) Opened last September, it’s the bakery outpost of Bread Nation, baker Eoin Cluskey’s bread wholesale business devoted to top-quality bread made the old-fashioned way. Bread 41 was along the way on our walk from our hotel to St. Stephens Green and, by the time we got there, it was already sold out of bread (it wasn’t even noon!). So I bought a salted chocolate chip cookie made with spelt and fat chocolate discs, and a salted-caramel croissant the size of a baby’s head as consolation and vowed to come back in an hour, when I was told more bread would be out of the oven.Thoughtfully made bread, like this cranberry and poppyseed sourdough, is worth a trip (or two) to Bread 41.
Photo by Shannon O' RourkeSixty minutes later, I was wandering the streets of Dublin, pulling hunks of bread from a still-warm miso einkorn loaf. It had a beautiful dark, crunchy crust and a moist, chewy center, with a little kick from the miso that caught you in the back of the throat. And because I was about to leave town—Dublin was a brief stopover on the way to family wedding outside the city—I also bought a chicken banh mi for the road. It was a pretty loose interpretation of a banh mi, but that didn’t bother me as I shoved pillowy housemade milk bread and house-fermented carrots into my mouth.While we were at the wedding, I started thinking about the danishes, which looked so pretty. And the malted loaf, which sounded so interesting. We returned to Dublin with less than 24 hours before our flight back to New York. Plenty of time for another trip to Bread 41 so I could stuff an oat porridge loaf—made with roasted oatmeal!—in my suitcase. What else was I going to do? Try another restaurant?
